 A B S T R A C T Turkey has made an ad hoc and piecemeal use of protective and incentive measures. Sufficient attention has not been given to the interdependence of these various instruments and to their net effect on different market destinations and sectors. By estimating and evaluating the quantitative indicators of incentives and comparative advantage, this study attempts to quantify the incidence of the system of protection and incentives in Turkish manufacturing in 1981. The findings are as follows: (a) Both nominal and effective protection are high and differ substantially among sectors, between public and private firms, and between domestic and export markets. (b) Tariff redundancy exists in a number of sectors. (c) There is a substantial bias against the private sector, due to a lower input protection in the public sector and to the substantial interest subsidy granted to public firms. (d) There is a heavy bias against exports in spite of generous export subsidies. (e) The domestic resource cost in a large number of sectors is high and differs substantially among sectors. (f) The domestic resource cost is substantially higher in the public sector, indicating a higher inefficiency in that sector. (g) Social profitability, on average, is higher in the private sector. Mi) Wide differences exist between social and private profitability among sectors and between public and private firms, indicating the presence of price distortions both in the product and factor markets. To rationalize resource allocation in Turkey, the wide variations in protection and subsidies among manufacturing sectors, between public and private firms, and between domestic and export markets need to be gradually narrowed. This requires substantial restructuring not only in import protection but also in the whole incentive system. The needed measures include: (1) the elimination of quantitative restrictions; (2) a reduction in the average tariff rate and a narrowing of the variation around it; (3) the elimination of preferential credit to the state economic enterprises; (4) a granting of duty-free access to all imported inputs for export production; and (5) the continuation of a realistic exchange rate policy with a gradual elimination of export subsidies following the reduction in import protection. The policy measures introduced in December 1983 and January 1984 are steps in the right direction. However, the new tariff and export rebate rates were set in an ad hoc manner without an analytical back-up to work out their impact on effective rates.

 INTRODUCTION The growth of Turkey's manufacturing output has been impressive, averaging 10 percent in the First Perspective Plan period (1963-77). This can be ascribed mainly to the generous industrial incentive system created in 1963 and continuously enhanced thereafter. This system includes tax allowances, interest subsidies, export tax rebates, duty-free importation, tariffs, quantitative restrictions, export earnings retention as well as foreign exchange and credit priorities. These incentives, combined with the rapid expansion in domestic demand, increased profitability in the domestic market relative to the export market and created a resource-pull effect in basic import- substituting industries, particularly petroleum refining, transport equipment and vehicles, fertilizers, machinery, and basic metals, with public sector playing an important role. All these favorable developments should be judged, however, against the costs, namely the sub-optimal, high-cost, and inefficient firms created during the industrialization process and the protracted stagnation in employment and exports. These adverse developments could be attributable mainly to the fact that the industrial incentives provided very high, indefinite and indiscriminate import protection and created a heavy bias against employment and exports. The belated adjustment to the oil price increases and the consequent heavy short-term borrowing combined with the adverse effects of the incentive system created a deep and protracted balance of payments crisis in 1977. Due to the shortage of imported intermediates
 the growth rate of manufacturing output declined rapidly, becoming negative after 1977. In the early 1980, a far-reaching stabilization program was introduced and the incentive system was partially modified. The manufacturing industry responded favorably to the partial reversal of industrial policies. The rate of growth of manufacturing output has increased to 8.1 percent in 1981 and 6.0 percent in 1982; manufactured exports grew at 131.7 percent in 1981 and 55.0 percent in 1982. All these bring the industrial incentives into focus. A careful evaluation of the system of industrial incentives seems to be a precondition to redressing industrial policies so as to attain growth and stability in the Turkish economy. It is the purpose of this study to provide such an evaluation. By estimating and evaluating the quantitative indicators of incentives and comparative advantage, this study attempts to quantify the incidence of the system of protection and incentives in Turkish manufacturing in 1981. The effects of industrial incentives are reflected in the following two sets of indicators: (a) indicators of incentives: nominal protection coefficient (NPC), effective protection coefficient (EPC) and effective subsidy coefficient (ESC); and (b) indicators of comparative advantage: domestic resource cost (DRC) and social profitability coefficient (SPC). 1/ These coefficients were estimated by using data obtained from a sample survey of 123 public and private 1/ For their description, interpretation, and estimation, see Balassa (1977, 1982).

INTRODUCTION The manufacturing industry in Turkey has been considered the main instrument of rapid growth, structural change and self- sufficiency. As such it has usually been the most favored sector of the economy. Resources have been channelled into it through heavy public sector investment, particularly in import-substituting basic industries, and through generous financial incentives coupled with a high level of protection for private investment. Replacing imports of non-durable consumer goods and their inputs with domestic production did not encounter much difficulty and the first stage of import substitution was completed with success by the early 1960s. The second stage which involves the replacement of imports of intermediate inputs and producer and consumer durables, followed and was intensified in the 1970s. Compared with the products of the first stage, these products are more capital-, skill-, and import-intensive. A successful second stage of import substitition, therefore, depends on the availability of capital, skills, and imports. But the policies pursued in the 1970s were not conducive to generating them. Moreover, the high level of import protection combined with an overvalued exchange rate created an anti-export bias, and export disincentive resulting in stagnating export revenues in the 1960s and 1970s. Rising import requirements had to be financed increasingly by
 - 5 - external resources and workers' remittances, the latter equalled to 93 percent of total merchandised exports in 1974. With a constantly rising incremental capital-output ratio, increasing volumes of external resources were needed to supplement insufficient domestic savings. Adjustment to the oil price increases and to the world depression that followed, was considerably delayed. Despite insufficient voluntary savings and stagnating exports, the pace of industrialization was maintained after 1973. But the consequent deficit financing accelerated inflation. Short term external borrowing mounted, and by 1978, external borrowing possibilities were exhausted. Imports declined and production and investment came to a standstill by the end of 1979. Since 1980 a series of policly reforms have been introduced to stabilize the economy. These reforms include: (a) An initial large devaluation in 1980 followed by daily adjustment of the exchange rate. (b) Higher export incentives: subsidized credit, priority and duty-free access to imported inputs for export production, tax rebates, elimination of licensing and relaxation of price controls in exports and simplification of regulations and centralization of administration. (c) Partial import liberalization: elimination of the quota list, shifting some imports to the more liberalized list and reduction in guarantee deposits.
 - 6 - (d) Tax reforms to mobilize domestic resources and restructure investment allowances. (e) Reorganization of the capital market: deregulation of interest rates and legislation for strengthening the capital market. (f) Relaxation of direct controls: decontrolling the selling prices of most state economic enterprises (SEE) and simplification of regulations and procedures. The economy as a whole, and the manufacturing industry in particular, responded favorably to the policy reforms. Inflation fell from 100 percent in 1980 to 30 percent in 1982. The growth rate of GNP and manufacturing value added became positive after 1980. Export performance of manufacturing industry has been impressive. In real terins manufactured exports increased by 131.7 percent and 55.0 percent in 1981 and 1982, respectively. International confidence has been restored. These favorable results, however, have been accompanied by rising unemployment, falling real wages, and declining investment. This chapter provides an overview of the manufacturing industry in Turkey in the last two decades. Section 2 presents the basic data on Turkey's manufacturing sector in the 1960s and 1970s. Section 3 discusses the sources of growth. Finally, Section 4 takes up the principal achievements and problems of Turkey's manufacturing sector.

Corporation Tax Allowances Amendments were made to the Corporation Tax in 1980 to allow industrial exporters with annual export revenues exceeding $250,000 to deduct 20 percent of their export revenues from taxable income. This incentive has also been extended to exporters of fresh fruit and vegetables and to firms engaged in tourism. Contracting companies abroad are fully exempted from the corporation and income tax. If the exportation is done through a trading company, one fourth of the tax deduction is given to the trading company.

Temporary Import Scheme This scheme was introduced in 1970 to allow industrialists holding a purchase order from a foreign firm to import the required inputs. Initially, industrialists deposited tariffs on the requisite imports, which were then refunded in full upon export. Since 1980, intermediate inputs have been imported duty-free and the foreign exchange allocation under this scheme may go up to 80 percent of the export revenues. The realized foreign exchange allocation under the temporary import regime has been negligible (less than one percent of total non- oil imports on average). Apart from the traditional exports such as cereals, nuts, raisins, figs and metal ores, a variety of industrial commodities (meat, margarine, olive oil, etc.) have also been subject to export licensing. Minimum export prices for various agricultural and industrial exports have also been set, primarily to prevent capital flight. In 1980, price controls on exports were substantially reduced and export licensing was relaxed. The export regime was further

The sensitivity of the estimated coefficients to prices and the difficulty involved in estimating world prices are well known. Although maximum care has been given to obtain the best available data, the possibility of errors, particularly in estimates of world prices, still remains.  - 56 - But before these results are presented, two points need mentioning. Effective protection indicates the combined effect of output and input protection on the processing activity. It is a measure of the protection of value added and is superior to nominal protection in describing the structure of protection.
 - 70 - The value of effective protection is determined by (a) the value of the nominal protection on output, (b) the value of the nominal protection on input, and (c) the value-added ratio of the processing activity. It is derived by adjusting the EPC for the difference between profit taxes and the interest actually paid by the firm and the "normal" profit tax and interest cost. In addition to the protection on their output and inputs, the subsidies the firms obtained through the following incentive measures were also taken into consideration in the estimation of the ESCs. These measures were discussed in Chapter II and will be stated here briefly. (a) Preferential medium-term credit: subsidized credit is given to investment projects in the priority areas designated in annual programs. The subsidy element varies according to the region

It represents the value of the domestic resources expended in saving or earning a unit of foreign exchange, valued in domestic currency at the shadow exchange rate. CONCLUSIONS Turkey has erected a complex system of industrial incentives since the early 1960s which is characterized by its high, indefinite and indiscriminate import protection and heavy bias against exports and employment. Under this system and heavy public sector involvement, resources have been channelled into import-substituting manufacturing industries. This, coupled with a rapid domestic demand expansion, produced favorable results in the first stage of import substitution. During the second stage of import substitution, however, the adverse effects of Turkey's system of incentives began to emerge and contributed to the downturn in the Turkish economy in the second half of the 1970s. In conjunction with a stabilization program, industrial incentives have been partially reversed since the early 1980s, to which manufacturing industry has responded favorably. The incentive system needs further restructuring, however, if there is to be a more rational allocation of resources and a resumption of stability and growth in the Turkish economy. This study aims to contribute to this end by estimating and evaluating the quantitative indicators of incentives and comparative advantage in Turkish manufacturing industries in 1981. The underlying data are from the sample survey of 1,23 firms in 66 sub-sectors. What follows are the major findings of this study.
 - 118 - 1. Nominal protection on output, measured by price comparison, is high: 32 percent for total manufacturing. This rate, morever, underestimates the actual protection granted to manufacturing output through high tariff rates and the complex system of QRs, because it is not adjusted for quality differentials between foreign and domestic products. The variation in nominal protection among sub-sectors, between public and private firms, and between domestic and export markets is also very high. 2. Tariff rates are very high for finished products (they are as high as 261 percent for plastic goods). These tariff rates are higher than the nominal protection rates estimated through price comparison. There may have been tariff redundancy in 11 of these 66 sectors, even if quality differentials are taken into consideration. For most intermediate goods and food products, tariff rates are low and the nominal protection rates estimated by price comparison exceed the tariff rates (in 23 sectors out of the 66): the difference between the two rates indicates the protective effect of QRs. Quality differentials are not factored in, so this protective effect is underestimated. 3. On average, nominal protection on output is higher in the private sector than in the public sector (39 percent vs. 25 percent, for total manufacturing). This is explained partly by product differentiation and partly by the fact that SEEs are not free to exploit market conditions fully in setting their selling prices.
 - 119 - 4. There is a substantial anti--export bias in output protection. Nominal protection rates for total manufacturing are 34 percent on domestic and 7 percent on export sales. It appears that the export tax rebate scheme is not sufficient to compensate for the high nominal protection granted to the domestic market through the tariff structure and QRs. The generous export subsidies in the form of tax and interest preferences, however, moderate the anti-export bias on output. Further restructuring of the system of incentives is needed to produce equalized effective subsidy rates for the two markets. 5. On average, effective protection on output is higher than nominal protection (81 percent vs. 32 percent, for total manufacturing). This is because input protection is lower than the output protection (20 percent vs. 32 percent). In addition, the variation in effective protection among sub-sectors, between public and private firms, and between domestic and export markets is very high. 6. Effective protection, on average, is higher in the public sector than in the private sector (97 percent vs. 69 percent, for total manufacturing). This is created by lower input protection in the public sector due to its duty-free access to most imported inputs and to the relatively low support prices granted in 1981 to agricultural products processed by some of the SEEs. This anti-private--sector bias reflects the absence of a conscious and systematic policy of industrial protection giving due consideration to the interactions between input and
 - 120 - output protection; rather, Turkey has made an ad hoc and piecemeal use of protective measures. This bias also indicates that the efficiency is lower in the public sector, which therefore has required higher protection on value added. 7. There is a larger bias against exports in effective protection (the effective protection rate is 93 percent in the domestic market and -6 percent in the export market). In fact, in 31 sectors out of 53 and in total manufacturing the export market faces disprotection. Considering the emphasis on export promotion since 1980, the higher discrimination against exports in terms of value added seems to have been unintended. Rather, it indicates that in the imposition of protective measures in Turkey, the interdependence of the various protective instruments and their net effect on different market destinations and sectors and the combined effect of output and input protection do not receive sufficient attention. 8. The anti-export bias in effective protection is larger in the private sector than in the public sector. This is explained by the lower input protection in the public sector. 9. For total manufacturing the effective subsidy rate is substantially higher than the effective protection rate in the public sector (163 percent and 97 percent), but it is only marginally higher in the private sector (70 and 69 percent). The skewed distribution of interest and tax allowances in favor of the public sector increases the anti-private sector bias. 10. Subsidies on export sales in the form of interest and tax preferences are high. In fact, export subsidies turn the
 - 121 - protection of value added on export sales for total manufacturing from negative to positive (the rates of effective protection and subsidy on export sales are -6 and 37 percent, respectively). This reduces the anti-export bias from 99 percentage points to 82 percentage points, which is still very large. 11. The DRC for total manufacturing at actual capacity operation is 2.04, implying that the domestic resource cost under protection, on average, is 104 percent higher than that what it would have been in the absence of protection. In addition, the dispersion in DRCs among sub-sectors and between public and private sector is very wide. The DRCs in 27 sectors of the 66 are less than one, indicatinc a comparative advantage in these sectors. 12. The DRCs, on average, are substantially higher in the public sector, indicating greater inefficiency. For total manufacturing the DRCs for the public and private sectors are 3.76 and 1.63, respectively. In both sectors the full capacity DRCs are lower than the actual capacity DRCs. 13. Variation between the DRCs and the EPCs is high. Given the effect of the revaluation of fixed capital, the difference between the shadow and the actual rate of return to capital explains most of the deviation of the DRCs from the EPCs. The deviation is wider in the public sector owing to the wider difference between the shadow and the actual rate of return to capital in that sector (0.120 and -0.012, respectively).
 - 122 - 14. The SPCs, on average, are substantially higher in the private sector. For total manufacturing the SPC is -0.007 in the public sector and 0.062 in the private sector at actual capacity operation. In addition, variation among sub-sectors is very wide (ranging from -0.005 to 0.350). The full capacity SPCs are higher than the actual capacity SPCs. In the public sector for total manufacturing the SPC becomes positive at full capacity (0.015). 15. Wide differences are calculated between social and private profitability among sub-sectors and between public and private firms, indicating price distortions in the product and factor markets. Some of these distortions are policy-imposed; others are due to market imperfections. 2. POLICY GUIDELINES Detailed policy papers based on the findings of this study are being written separately. This section presents the general policy guidelines coming out of these findings. It also indicates the necessary follow-up studies to prepare a quantitative policy program to restructure Turkey's incentive system. Making allowance for the existence of differential incentives on the basis of infant industry and social and political considerations, the results indicate that to rationalize production and resource allocation there should be a gradual narrowing and eventual elimination of the wide variations in protection: (a) among manufacturing sub- sectors; (b) between public and private firms; and (c) between domestic
 - 123 - and export markets. It is desirable to do this with a pre-announced timetable to allow sufficient time for the firms to adjust to the new incentive system without much dislocation to the economy. To narrow the differences in protection among sub-sectors, QRs should be gradually lifted and protection be provided through tariffs only. In addition, with the exception of luxury imports, tariffs should gradually be reduced (but increased in the case of some food products and intermediate inputs) to a target rate. Setting policies to achieve target rates of effective protection and effective subsidy requires further work. The tariff rates on inputs and outputs and the sectoral subsidy rates which would generate the desired effective rates can be estimated in a follow-up study by iteration. Narrowing the differences in effective protection between the public and private sectors necessitates reducing the differences between them in input protection. Input protection in the public sector is relatively low, placing the public sector in a favorable position vis-a- vis the private sector in protecting value-added. One of the reasons for the lower input protection in the public sector is its privilege of duty-free importation of foreign inputs even when they are to be used in production for the domestic market. Cessation of this privilege would contribute to the equalization of the effective rates in the two sectors. Large differences in the ESCs between the public and the private sectors in favor of the former are due to the additional subsidies granted to the public firms and the negative subsidies on non- preferential credit given to the private firms. The transaction tax on
 - 124 - non-preferential credit to the private sector should be eliminated to reduce the negative subsidies. The single most significant subsidy element which increases the ESC in the public sector is the heavily subsidized credits to public firms from public financial institutions. Elimination of this privilege not only would substantially contribute to the equalization of the ESCs in the public and private firms, but also would put some discipline into the financial operation of the public firms. It is crucial to eliminate the long-standing anti-export bias to attain and maintain stability and growth in the Turkish economy. The bias against exports in the effective rates is so large that it cannot be eliminated by merely increasing export tax rebates, due to budgetary implications. Rather, action should be taken to lower import protection. Duty-free importation of inputs used for export production -- allowed for only a part of inputs in the private sector under the current system -- should be extended to all inputs. Given this, a follow-up study should be done to calculate the required tariff rates on inputs and outputs and the required export tax rebate rate and other subsidies which would equalize the ESCs on domestic and export sales. In addition, export subsidies should be related to value added in exports rather than to export revenue. 1/ In parallel with the reduction in import protection, export subsidies should gradually be 1/ Legislation was passed in 1980 to relate the export subsidies to value added, but implementation was postponed.
 - 125 - reduced and more emphasis should be given to the exchange rate policy in export promotion. In the policy design for eliminating the wide differences among sub-sectors, between public and private sectors, and between domestic and export markets, special care should be taken to set the magnitude and the timing of the policy changes in order: (a) to avoid major dislocations in the economy and achieve a smooth transition; (b) to take account of the relationship with the EEC; and (c) to avoid abrupt changes in government revenue. Particular consideration should be given to the implication of the policy changes on employment and income distribution. 3. POSTSCRIPT Since December 1983 the Turkish Government has introduced a series of policies related to the system of incentives and protection. These policies represent an important turning point in the process of adjustment. They include: 1. A substantial import liberalization. In value terms, about 80 percent of the items in Liberalized List II were freed from QRs. The remaining 20 percent are still subject to licensing. The new import regime increases the share of free imports in total imports from the 18 percent of 1983 to 60 percent. In addition, a list of banned imports was also introduced to replace the previous implicit "Prohibited List". This list has some 207 items including agricultural products, drugs, etc. whose import had also been banned under the previous regime.
 - 126 - 2. A restructuring of the tariff system. The tariff rates for 494 products were changed: more than 80 percent of them were reduced considerably. The pattern of low rates for intermediate foods and food products but higher rates for finished goods was preserved. In addition, the old levy list was extended to 75 products and the levies were substantially increased. This list includes basic consumer durables such as cars, TV sets, stereo sets, washers, dryers, and refrigerators. 3. A centralization of import administration. Under the new system all authority on matters related to imports (such as issuing licenses, shifting items among lists, changing tariffs and levy rates, and granting the right to purchase foreign exchange), previously dispersed among various ministries and the Central Bank, is centralized into a newly formed under- secretariat under the Deputy Prime Minister. 4. A substantial liberalization of the foreign exchange regime. This includes authorization of commercial banks to set their own exchange rate within the 6 percent point spread above or below the rate established daily by the Central Bank, freeing of restrictions on foreign exchange transactions by Turkish nationals, the permission for Turkish nationals to invest up to $2 million abroad, and the elimination of travel restrictions. 5. Re-emphasizing the role of a flexible exchange rate policy in the continued export orientation of the economy. 6. Continuation of export subsidies in the form of interest and tax allowances.
 - 127 - 7. A gradual reduction in export tax rebate rates (on April 2, 1984, by 20 percent, and then in September 1984 by another 25 percent), to rely more on the exchange rate than on direct subsidies in export promotion. 8. A reduction of the foreign exchange retention rate from 50 percent of export earnings to 20 percent. Under the new system this incentive is extended to all non-manufacturing exports. 9. A reduction in the transaction tax on non-preferential credit to the private sector from 15 percent to 3 percent. 10. A reaffirmation that SEEs will be free to set their own prices with certain exceptions, such as sugar, coal, and fertilizer. All these policy changes are in line with the guidelines coming out of this study and would contribute to the rationalization of the incentive system substantially. The policy action related to the reduction of tariff rates and export rebate rates, however, deserves further discussion. In evaluating the resource-pull effect of a system of incentives, effective rates are superior to nominal rates. In combining the protection on outputs and inputs and in incorporating various subsidies granted to the firm, effective rates measure the protection (and subsidy) extended to value added. What matters for the firm is the actual protection (and subsidy) obtained on value added. In rationalizing the incentive system one should set target effective rates to be achieved in a certain period of time. Given these, rates one can then calculate by iteration the required subsidy rates and the tariff rates on outputs and inputs. The iterative
 - 128 - procedure produces a timetable for the changes in the tariff and subsidy rates which would gradually equalize the effective rates among sectors and between public and private firms. To eliminate the anti-export bias, export rebate rates and other export subsidies should also be included in the iterations to calculate the required rates to equalize the effective rates on domestic and export sales. In the recent policy changes the emphasis of the Government has been on the nominal rates. The new tariff and export rebate rates were set in an ad hoc manner without analytical back-up to work out their impact on the effective rates. It is not known, therefore, in what direction the effective rates have been changed by the recent policy changes or whether the variation in effective rates among sectors, between public and private firms, and between domestic and export sales has been narrowed or widened. The confusion about the role of foreign exchange should also be considered. To encourage exports the policy package aims to rely more on exchange rate policy than on direct export subsidies. This is why a 40 percent decrease in export rebate rates was planned for 1984 in parallel with the commitment to a more realistic exchange rate policy. But a realistic exchange rate policy would increase the net rate of protection in both the domestic and the export markets in the same way; it would not reduce an anti-export bias. However, it would free direct export subsidies from the role of compensating for the effects of an overvalued exchange rate. Reducing the anti-export bias depends on the relative changes in tariff rates on outputs and inputs, export rebate rates and various
 - 129 - subsidy rates. From the way that the recent policy decisions were taken, however, it is not known whether the anti-export bias is reduced. Overall, the recent policy changes constitute an important step towards the rationalization of the incentive system. However, changes in the tariff and rebate rates were rnade in an ad hoc fashion without any consideration given to the interactions between them. It is not known, therefore, whether these policy actions can produce the desired results. Under these circumstances the need for the proposed follow-up study is even more important.

doc.repnme: Protection and incentives in Turkish manufacturing : an evaluation of policies and their impact in 1981
doc.abstracts: Turkey has made piecemeal use of protective and incentive measures and has not given sufficient attention to the interdependence of these instruments and their net effect on different market destinations and sectors. Quantification of the incidence of the system of protection and incentives in Turkish manufacturing in 1981 led to the following findings: (i) both nominal and effective protection are high and differ substantially among sectors, between public and private firms, and between domestic and export markets; (ii) tariff redundancy exists in many sectors; (iii) there is a substantial bias against the private sector; (iv) there is a heavy bias against exports in spite of generous export subsidies; (v) domestic resource cost is high in many sectors and differs substantially among them; (vi) the cost is substantially higher in the public sector; (vii) social profitability is higher in the private sector; and (viii) wide differences exist between social and private profitability among sectors and between public and private firms. These wide variations need to be narrowed, which will require restructuring in the whole incentive system, not just in import protection.
